snippet: In a lamentable ruling, the Supreme Court decided to allow Greece, N.Y., to begin town meetings with a prayer, almost always from a Christian chaplain.
abstract: Editorial criticizes Supreme Court ruling that will allow Greece, NY, to begin town hall meetings with prayer; contends decision undermines the values of pluralism and inclusion that are central to the First Amendment; agrees Justice Elena Kagan's dissent that such prayers present a case-by-case problem, and that they cannot be accepted when they serve to exclude citizens of different faiths.
lead_paragraph: In a lamentable ruling, the Supreme Court decided to allow Greece, N.Y., to begin town meetings with a prayer, almost always from a Christian chaplain.
